content: Obama is not proposing a 'single payer system' like the kind in Canada and Britain. There won't be any 'government-run healthcare': The Obama-Biden Plan On health care reform, the American people are too often offered two extremes -- government-run health care with higher taxes or letting the insurance companies operate without rules. Barack Obama and Joe Biden believe both of these extremes are wrong, and that’s why they’ve proposed a plan that strengthens employer coverage, makes insurance companies accountable and ensures patient choice of doctor and care without government interference. The Obama-Biden plan provides affordable, accessible health care for all Americans, builds on the existing health care system, and uses existing providers, doctors, and plans. Under the Obama-Biden plan, patients will be able to make health care decisions with their doctors, instead of being blocked by insurance company bureaucrats. Under the plan, if you like your current health insurance, nothing changes, except your costs will go down by as much as $2,500 per year. If you don’t have health insurance, you will have a choice of new, affordable health insurance options. Read more here: http://change.gov/agenda/health_care_agenda/

content: quote: Originally posted by Boospar: I do not at present have a horrible private insurance story. A large part of the reason that we find ourselves at this point is simple - medical care costs have skyrocketed in this country over the past couple decades, and insurance companies have a habit of denying many treatments as being cost-prohibitive or outright denying coverage altogether for folks with a number of pre-existing conditions. As an example, a few weeks ago I had to go to the ER for stiches. Between what I paid and what my insurance company paid, the total cost billed by the hospital was over $850 - for 14 stitches. Another example is the Epinephrin autoinjector (EpiPen) that I have to have as a result of having severe allergic reactions to shellfish - a 2 pack costs over $450 between what I pay and my insurance's payment towards them. That's why there is a big push towards health care reform.

content: Obama is not proposing a 'single payer system' like the kind in Canada and Britain. There won't be any 'government-run healthcare': The Obama-Biden Plan On health care reform, the American people are too often offered two extremes -- government-run health care with higher taxes or letting the insurance companies operate without rules. Barack Obama and Joe Biden believe both of these extremes are wrong, and that’s why they’ve proposed a plan that strengthens employer coverage, makes insurance companies accountable and ensures patient choice of doctor and care without government interference. The Obama-Biden plan provides affordable, accessible health care for all Americans, builds on the existing health care system, and uses existing providers, doctors, and plans. Under the Obama-Biden plan, patients will be able to make health care decisions with their doctors, instead of being blocked by insurance company bureaucrats. Under the plan, if you like your current health insurance, nothing changes, except your costs will go down by as much as $2,500 per year. If you don’t have health insurance, you will have a choice of new, affordable health insurance options. Read more here: http://change.gov/agenda/health_care_agenda/

content: quote: Originally posted by Boospar: I do not at present have a horrible private insurance story. A large part of the reason that we find ourselves at this point is simple - medical care costs have skyrocketed in this country over the past couple decades, and insurance companies have a habit of denying many treatments as being cost-prohibitive or outright denying coverage altogether for folks with a number of pre-existing conditions. As an example, a few weeks ago I had to go to the ER for stiches. Between what I paid and what my insurance company paid, the total cost billed by the hospital was over $850 - for 14 stitches. Another example is the Epinephrin autoinjector (EpiPen) that I have to have as a result of having severe allergic reactions to shellfish - a 2 pack costs over $450 between what I pay and my insurance's payment towards them. That's why there is a big push towards health care reform.

content: Obama is not proposing a 'single payer system' like the kind in Canada and Britain. There won't be any 'government-run healthcare': The Obama-Biden Plan On health care reform, the American people are too often offered two extremes -- government-run health care with higher taxes or letting the insurance companies operate without rules. Barack Obama and Joe Biden believe both of these extremes are wrong, and that’s why they’ve proposed a plan that strengthens employer coverage, makes insurance companies accountable and ensures patient choice of doctor and care without government interference. The Obama-Biden plan provides affordable, accessible health care for all Americans, builds on the existing health care system, and uses existing providers, doctors, and plans. Under the Obama-Biden plan, patients will be able to make health care decisions with their doctors, instead of being blocked by insurance company bureaucrats. Under the plan, if you like your current health insurance, nothing changes, except your costs will go down by as much as $2,500 per year. If you don’t have health insurance, you will have a choice of new, affordable health insurance options. Read more here: http://change.gov/agenda/health_care_agenda/

As an example, a few weeks ago I had to go to the ER for stiches. Between what I paid and what my insurance company paid, the total cost billed by the hospital was over $850 - for 14 stitches. Another example is the Epinephrin autoinjector (EpiPen) that I have to have as a result of having severe allergic reactions to shellfish - a 2 pack costs over $450 between what I pay and my insurance's payment towards them. That's why there is a big push towards health care reform.
reply: Just as a matter of interest Phoenix how much was your insurance premium this year (if it's not a rude question)? $850 seems a lot of money for perhaps an hours work. I wonder how much it would have cost if you'd gone to your local vet and asked him/her to stitch you up, probably a lot less. You might not have got a local anaesthetic though. In my rugby playing days I was stitched up by both a doctor and a (equine) vet and have to say that the vet's handiwork was quicker, neater, left less of a scar and (being local free because I wanted to get back on the pitch) a lot less painful than the doctor's .

content: quote: Originally posted by Bladensburg: quote: Originally posted by JNickel185748: I lived in the UK for four years and had to go to locals for certain things. Saw it up close and personal. No thank you! .05 The NHS has become one of the worst examples in recent years and it's not all down to the Labour party policies of the last decade, a significant proportion of the blame must lie with Thatcher's Conservatives for introducing a culture or management and careerism in the '80s. On the other hand a lot of Americans who get medical treatment, particularly those who get it subsidised, seem to forget that they only get it so promptly because there are millions of Americans who can't afford care and therefore conveniently die before they can clog up waiting lists. Your post is BS, AMericans can NOT be turned away for health care. NO hospital turns away a patient that can not pay. It's illegal to do so. So for you to say Americans Die is a LIE. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

content: quote: This is old news, aside from someone admitting it. Conservatives have been saying this for a long time. Yes and everyone needs to be saying this non stop. Americans have short term memories or something. We have other huge problems as well but we tend to focus (majority wise) on the next news story whatever that may be. Currently my Mother is very sick and has been to two doctors so far. She has had several tests and blood work. The most recent doctor saw her for 5 minutes total. The first 1.5 minutes was my Mom (Nurse for 30+ years) trying to explain her symptoms (gradual increase in severity for almost a year till bang...real bad) This doc stops her short and says I know exactly what is wrong...you have a bladder wall infection. He prescribes some antibiotics and she takes her first couple and breaks out in hives/rashes/getting sick. He doesn't even call her in to see her. Just orders a different antibiotic. She feels better until the last day of antibiotics. Now she is worse than ever. He basically says he does not know what is wrong. 5 minutes of face time and 2 prescriptions later he gives up. We have the choice of going somewhere else. What will it be like when WE DON’T HAVE THAT CHOICE??? This is not a secrete agenda of this administration. This is an open in your face as we step on your head agenda. Why do we have to wait until we (or a loved one) are near death with sickness to grasp the severity of this upcoming situation? Fix the current system…don’t throw it away for something worse to gain political votes.

content: quote: Okay. As long as the heathcare system provides good care who cares? Private insureance exits for one reaso...the bottom line...better known as profit... or sub-prime health care?! Private insurance exists for the bottom line. Duh! So is that evil? What is bad from this is that the actual ability to have competing companies (health/insurance) does not exist. "Who wants to pay higher medical costs/premiums/insurance...show of hands...anyone (crickets)...how about a nod or just wink...anyone? Come on...someone has to want to pay more..." The point is...the GOVERNMENT cannot compete in quality/costs with private. If they could then we would have done this 233 years ago. And by the way...who decides on what is considered QUALITY TREATMENT? You? Today yes possible tomorrow there is no freaking way you will be heard. That is the main issue to me.
